Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Computational Studies of Water Dynamics at DNA Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Steven Corcelli of the University of Notre Dame is supported by a CAREER award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program to carry out research to develop computational methods for the characterization of water dynamics at DNA interfaces. While it is established that hydration is essential to the stability and function of biomolecules, its role as an active player in important biological processes, such as allosteric regulation, folding, reaction mechanisms and molecular recognition is not fully understood. Two complementary studies are being carried out in Corcelli's program to elucidate the extent to which water confined in the major and minor grooves of DNA exhibits dynamics that are different from the bulk. In the first project, Coumarin 102 is being computed in DNA at various positions within the strand. In the second project, novel infrared probes, N-nitrile-deoxyuridine and N-nitrile-deoxyguanosine expected to reveal information about water dynamics are being studied in a simulated DNA environment.

The work is having a broad impact on our understanding of water in biological systems as well as through the development by Corcelli of a special mathematical methods course aimed at Chemistry students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project had two principle thrusts: (1) to understand how water behaves differently in the vicinity of DNA, and (2) to develop new theopretical tools for interpreting infrared spectra that report on the structure and dynamics of proteins. All of the work utilized theory and computation to directly support experimental stdueies. Every effort was made to compute observables for an unambiguous comparison between theory and experiment; the calculations provide molecular-level insight that aids in the interpretation and design of experiments.  

(1) DNA Solvation Dynamics. Solvation dynamics experiments interrogate the collective motions of a molecular environment responding to the electronic excitation of a fluorescent probe molecule. Solvation dynamics measurements in biomolecular contexts have revealed dynamics on time scales ranging from femtoseconds to tens of nanoseconds whose physical interpretation is controversial. Some have maintained that the experiments are reporting on anomalously slow hydration dynamics, while others suggest the slower time scales in solvation dynamics responses are due to biomolecular motions. As part of this project, my research group conducted a systematic computational investigation to connect experimentally measured solvation dynamics responses to specific microscopic motions of a DNA dodecamer, in aqueous solution. These studies have shown definitively that the slow responses are due to motions within the DNA itself. This is a significant departure from previous interpretations that focused on hydration dynamics, but one which will catalyze the use of solvation dynamics measurements to characterize ultrafast biomolecular dynamics on time scales that are inaccessible to other techniques.

(2) Infrared reporters of biomolecular structure and dynamics. Infrared (IR) spectroscopy offers several advantages for the study of biomolecular structure and dynamics, including sub-picosecond time resolution and applicability to systems—such as membrane proteins and intrinsically disordered proteins—that pose special challenges to X-ray crystallography and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. A flexible computational strategy for computing the IR absorption spectra of vibrational probes in proteins and DNA was developed with support from the NSF. Computational studies of three different IR reporters have been performed: (1) nitrile (C≡N) probes of biomolecular hydration, (2) C−D and C−D2 probes of the protonation state of titratable residues in proteins, and (3) phosphate reporters of local electrostatic and hydration environment. Our methods quantitatively reproduce experimental shifts in nitrile vibrational spectra as a function of solvent polarity, and we demonstrated that C–D vibrational probes are exceptionally sensitive reporters of the protonation state of nearby titratable groups, which is often critical to protein stability and function. The asymmetric phosphate stretch was found to be a reliable reporter of the electrostatic fields of its solvent environment, which is an important discovery because phosphates are so ubiquitous in biology (e.g. in phospholipid membranes, DNA, RNA, ADP, ATP, and phosphorylated proteins). This work will likely lead to new biophysical techniques based on infrared spectroscopy to better understand the structure, dynamics, and hydration of molecules in biological contexts.
